Award.AwardTitle: AToL: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Resolving the Trunk of the Angiosperm Tree and Twelve of its Thorniest Branches
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Flowering plants (angiosperms) are the largest (>270,000 species), most diverse, and economically most important group of green plants. Understanding the origin, patterns of variation, and relationships among angiosperms is challenging. Despite progress, relationships among major groups remain unclear, as do relationships within major subgroups (e.g., roses and allies). Our multigene and genomics approaches target 12 problematic groups and subgroups; their resolution should clarify the framework for angiosperm phylogeny. We also will develop the first comprehensive non-DNA database for angiosperms and populate it with key morphological features. Together, our approaches will lay groundwork for collaboratively building the tree of all 12,000 genera of angiosperms.

Broader Impacts: The angiosperm tree will be useful to comparative biologists including physiologists, ecologists, paleobiologists, and genomicists. The Botany Browser we develop will provide an informatics infrastructure to bring many data resources to users' desktops. The Angiosperm MorphBank will facilitate group diagnosis, analyses of character distributions, and study of fossils. Our interdisciplinary training of postdoctoral fellows and students will emphasize recruitment of minorities. Our website on angiosperm diversity will be valuable to researchers, K-12 teachers, and students. We will construct pages for the Tree of Life Web Project including TreeHouses designed for K-12 students and teachers. A movable museum exhibit highlighting advances in our understanding of plant phylogeny will be distributed to museums represented in our project. Posters detailing the angiosperm tree will be designed and distributed and made available on CD. Additional outreach will be provided through presentations to local public schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The origin and diversification of flowering plants (angiosperms) was one of the greatest events in the history of the Earth. The oldest angiosperm fossils date from 130-136 million years ago, followed by a rapid rise to ecological dominance before the end of the Cretaceous. Flowering plants have since diversified to include 300,000-400,000 species occupying nearly all terrestrial and many aquatic environments. Angiosperms provide most of our foods and many of our medicines, and account for the vast majority of terrestrial photosynthesis and carbon sequestration. Understanding angiosperm relationships and evolutionary history is therefore of great importance for many reasons including an improved understanding of biodiversity as well as crop improvement. A better understanding of relationships and diversity in flowering plants will also help clarify fundamental processes underlying plant/animal associations and the assembly of entire ecosystems.

We used DNA sequences and broad taxonomic sampling to establish a phylogenetic framework (tree of relationships) for angiosperms, determining the major clades (groups) and their relationships and revealing the basalmost or ancestral lineages. We analyzed broad patterns of morphological and genome evolution, integrated fossils, dated the time of divergence of all major groups of flowering plants, and assessed rates of species diversification in various lineages (that is, what groups have radiated rapidly? what groups may be in decline?). This work has fundamentally changed our understanding of angiosperm relationships and facilitated a major reclassification of this huge group which is a major component of the tree of life.

Our trees of relationship have been widely used by the biological and educational community, providing a crucial framework in diverse fields including comparative genomics, ecology, agriculture, physiology, and paleobiology, while providing new insights into adaptation, speciation, community assembly, and ecosystem functioning. This framework has also provided the stimulus for obtaining major new insights into the origin and early diversification of the flower.

We also developed new computational and informatic tools. Our Tree of Life Knowledge Information Network (ToLKIN) provides an environment for depositing, maintaining, and navigating results, with tools to facilitate the integration of existing data from differing sources (e.g., MorphBank, TreeBASE, GenBank). Links automate submission of AToL-generated data from ToLKIN back to these repositories.  This tool is now being widely used by other researchers building other portions of the tree of life.

We have also developed several major public outreach components as part of of this project. We developed (with NSF CIPRes and Euphorbia PBI project) an exhibit (~1000 square feet) at the Yale Peabody Museum entitled, “Travels in the Great Tree of Life” (opened 2/16/2008). It appeals to all ages and includes: two short films on ToL research and its importance (including the importance of our angiosperm AToL), interactives (e.g., a game for children) on character evolution (that is how characteristics evolve), and highlights convergence and extreme divergence of characters in organisms. Our research was also featured in the NOVA special, “First Flower”, another useful teaching tool.
